Triggering Event: After years of meticulous research, today's lab experiment was meant to be her magnum opus. Yet, as she struggled with the finicky equipment, her frustration grew. Each failed attempt felt like a personal affront, another reminder that time was not on her side. She found herself shouting at the machine, "Why won't you work? Your predecessor never gave me this much trouble!" But the machine remained silent and unyielding, just like her late husband would whenever she sought comfort in their shared passion.

He had always been there for me when I needed him, but now he was gone, leaving me to navigate the world alone. My mind kept drifting back to the day he passed away, how his words still haunted me - "Don't let your frustrations consume you." I tried to push them aside, but it wasn't working. With each failure, my anger grew, until I finally snapped, shouting at the machine, "Why won’t you work? You were fine last week! Why is everything so different now?" It didn’t matter that the machine was just doing what it was programmed to do; all I could think about was how my life had fallen apart since then. The world felt darker, every day more difficult. And now, here I was, struggling to keep up with the demands of science while trying to hold together a shattered heart. I couldn't help but wonder if it was all worth it - maybe I should have stayed home, spent those hours grieving instead of throwing myself into this project. Triggering Event: She found herself absentmindedly chopping onions, tears stinging her eyes, as she remembered the last time they'd cooked together. A half-finished recipe lay untouched since his passing, guilt gnawing at her for not finishing it, for moving on while he couldn't. The knife slipped, nicking her finger. She sucked the blood, tasting salt and loss.
